comments.commentBody: Agreed completely. This new format feels like a daytime talk show. Terrible.

Completely unreadable as well as unscholarly and uninteresting. The only thing worse that reading it is the podcast which is like sitting at a middle school lunch table in the cafeteria.

On the plus side, the magazine is no longer the time suck it once was.

This is unreadable. This format has ruined our weekly tradition of reading the question, having a thoughtful discussion, and then reading the answer. The Times should hire an Ethicist, one scholar of ethics, to give stimulating responses grounded in field of ethics.  When we first started reading this years ago, the writer was excellent, giving consistently interesting, ethical answers. The most recent writer was not an ethicist; his answers were somewhat entertaining, but not necessarily ethical. This newest format is the worst. We can't get through it. Please do the ethical thing and for your column titled "Ethicist ", hire an ethicist.
And you chose the handle "W84me" and end your post with an emoticon? That's 2 weird 4 words!
It would also help matters tremendously if we once again removed ads for prescription drugs from TV.

There is something seriously amiss when one in four women, and one in seven men, is taking psychiatric medication. Record numbers of children are being diagnosed with Attention Deficit Disorder and medicated for it.

It takes me back to my childhood in the 50s and 60s, when I rarely took medicine. If I had a lot of extra energy, typical for me, my mother told me it was time to go outside and play. My friends and I rode our bikes all over my mid sized town in Idaho. It was an unhurried time, we had our leisure time and we had our school recesses, great for letting off steam.

Have we reached a point of resigned acceptance to the inordinate number of people being medicated? Perhaps a big part is living in a society which stresses being driven relentlessly, stress at work and even at play, as witnessed by helicopter parents whose children have nary an idle moment. Playing childhood sports has taken on a combative and aggressive tone, often instigated by parents pushing their child to be the next super talented player.

Perhaps the need for psychiatric care and to medicate would be less if we as a culture learned to appreciate more the simple pleasures, letting go of the constant striving to 'get ahead' which often seems to lead to nowhere but depression and anxiety.
That's what spouse and I see, too.  We're either all brilliant and infallible, or freaks of nature.

"To economists, the real world is often a special case" - Murphy's Law on Economics, circa 1981.

In the mid90s, I briefly worked with a new Econ graduate from a tier 1 school. I mentioned regret in not majoring in the field. She replied with her own: "Economics has basically become little more than applied mathematics."

In 79-82 roughly the period you describe, I was a wet behind the ears undergraduate studying econ geography in the Geog dept at the Univ of Arizona. One of their top guys in Economic Geography was Gordon Mulligan, from UBC. I remember quite vividly in my 1st class with him stating things in which I had no idea of the context: "In the field of Economic Geography there is at least more openness to various ideas." Implying that intellectually speaking Economics itself, perhaps his true interests, had been sown shut. Later he went on to mock Milton Friedman a bit ..."Uncle Miltie says..."

At the time I had no idea about the subtext but I too was frustrated in how conceptually narrow the economics I was being taught in my econ classes was. But Mulligan was clearly antagonistic to the straight-jacket impact the Chicago school of thought was having on the field. This may, in part, be because Geography itself is, in short hand, the study of how things vary over space. As an academic field it is far more deductive than most others. You observe generalities and then work back word. "The Rocky Mts start in Alaska and end at Cape Horn" that kind of thing.
Ah, Mr. Miller, my father's quote was ... "All perception; no substance."  I believe yours is the more accurate.

I am beyond a doubt one of those straight up geriatrics. Trying to decipher the texts my grand kids send to each other seems to me like listening to a conversation of "valley girls". All theatrics, no substance.

It's probably fair to think of texts as spoken English, which is informal, and emails as more formal written English. I dash off texts without worrying too much about punctuation or capitalization. But I edit and rewrite an email with the care I'd give to a letter requiring an envelope and a stamp.

BTW—NYT comments fall into the latter category.
I can hear the shade of H K Fowler laughing.  (Note the paucity of periods in "H" and "K".)  As a famous critic said, "Make it new" [sic].

Cost and revenue predictions can be difficult but dynamic scoring should work well provided honest likely alternatives are set forth with estimates of probability and reliability.

For example an article in The Upshot reported that individual health insurance might increase by 47% if the supreme court rules against subsidies in states without exchanges. This is based on experience from a handful of states that required insurance to insure those with preexisting conditions resulting in companies leaving the individual market. The obvious solution of prohibiting group discounts so all policies would be individual was not mentioned with the inflammatory projection.

Replacing payroll taxes with a VAT of just 4% and reduction in some business tax expenditures could be revenue neutral with no change in Social Security or Medicare. The change would also encourage full employment, higher salaries and economic growth. Would the CBO give an economic opinion free from political slant? Would the CBO say cutting payroll taxes could help the economy more than cutting income taxes because ... ?

The famously terse British have a knack for concision, to keep the badinage to a minimum.  When they'd caught the rebel leader, Sindh, in the Punjab, they simply telegraphed to HQ: "peccavi."  That's Latin for "we have sinned."

You would be quite right if convictions were for real crimes but it seems to me that an African-American can get convicted of some crime just by being near a white policeman who is not in a good mood.

Sorry, but this is not true. It is much easier for some folks to be convicted of felonies than others. When I was in college, I saw well off white kids sharing out cocaine and pot with literally no fear of the police arresting them. Even when the police showed up to a frat party to tell them to turn down the noise, they didn't search the place for illegal drugs, even when pot was clearly in the air. Contrast that with the police being called to quiet a party at a low income housing project and finding a marijuana joint in the process. How often do you think they would overlook it?

As often as not, felony convictions for non-violent offenses say something about your race or the race and mindset of the police officer who decided to arrest (or not arrest) you. Pretending that racial privilege doesn't play a huge role in determining who gets arrested and who gets a pass is just a lie.
There is nothing wrong with preferring to hire a person who has managed to avoid being convicted of a felony. Like it or not, it does say something about your character.
Ever think it was the supervisor that should have been fired?
Non-violent crimes should probably be purged after a fixed period, like bankruptcies.

This story of Mr. Mirsky, Menteer, Payne, and the millions like them is exceptionally tragic. However, you did not explain the true extent of the problem: America has over 2.2 million people enslaved in jails and over 75 million citizens free but with lifelong convictions, the vast majority of them for Unconstitutional victimless+consensual crimes like "drug" possession. The solution is not a campaign to "ban the box" until later in the job application process, when it will still tank their chances. The solution is to repeal all the unconstitutional victimless crimes on the books (because judges did not do their jobs of invalidating such lunacy) + to pardon (or give clemency to) every one of the approximately 70 million convicted of these victimless/consensual crimes. The main cause of all these arrests, and of all crime in the world (especially violent crime) is the drug prohibition laws. End those evil laws and most crime + violence in the world will end, overnight.
Then, we can take the $ we save and provide people with free housing, food, minimal income, college, internet, etc. to give all Americans the chance to contribute to the world to the best of their abilities.

Pardoning the 70 million convicted of victimless crimes (+ making all immigrants legal) will also greatly increase the wages of ALL Americans, who will not have to compete against illegal workers earning slave wages. We must stand up for human rights. As Pres. Jefferson said, no victim no crime.
That's what we see at our house, too.

Yes but people using Western Union knew they were using a new technology to communicate quickly to other people.  They knew they had to  write clearly in other situations.  Don't think that's true today.

Since the precursor to the internet, Western Union, charged a per-character fee, thrifty types sent sparing messages. When a newsman wired to Cary Grant to learn his age for a profile he was writing, he asked: How old Cary Grant?  To which Cary Grant responded:  He fine. How you?
